Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: There's a Indian man who knows who he is and seems interested in who others are. He recognizes something he won't understand but attempts to anyway. Why not. There's time in life to play with possibilities.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was great - very responsive and offered constructive criticism.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark Saxena
Instructor: Jeffrey Chow  Jeffrey Chow
Instructor: Jeffrey Chow  Although both teaching fellows were always available, Jeffrey Chow was in charge of the more teacher-to-student interactions.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Jeffrey and Alark effectively taught the class. They did a fantastic job. (Q 10 - 12).

Some of the material presented was a bit confusing at first, unless the student had a background or experience with international conferences/organizations. It should be explained to the student how complex the international law system is - maybe a better formal introduction of its history.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This was a real-world exercise and a pragmatic class.
The trip to COP18 and the simulation COP we did. Also, because I really clicked with my client, working with them turned out to be great.
Experiencing romance under such caustic circumstances.
The field trip to COP 18. It was a great learning experience, and very well organized. The class did a great job of preparing the students for participation in the conference.
The vast and diverse number of guest speakers. They all provided a different views of international conferences and organizations.
Having an opportunity to be involved with a real world projects.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Guaranteeing stakeholders are on board.

The lectures. Since they were all guest lectures, some of them were good but others were not. I think having a good number of guest lectures is great, but that this course could have benefited from some consistency. Maybe it would be good to have a guest lecture every other class, and consistent lectures given by the same person every other class. I feel like I got to understand the UNFCCC process well through my work with my client, but would not have otherwise. It would have been great to have one lecture on the AWG-KP, one on the ADP, etc. explaining how each track works, what issues are important in each track, the history of what has gone down between countries/blocs in each track, etc. Also, a lecture on the cultural/political context of our destination country (Qatar this year) would have been very useful. Also, the simulation was very well done and I got a ton out of it, but the course did not prepare us for it ahead of time; those of us who had no experience with the COP had to just figure out how things worked as we went.
can not think of any.

Although the number of speakers was great and provided a diverse set of views and backgrounds, there was a lack of formal introduction/background provided for these speakers ahead of time. Many times, we were told who was speaking a few days or less before they came, therefore limiting the time we had to prepare questions and investigate their background.
The TAs need to be more organized.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective
n/a
N/A

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: They were very strong academically. I still feel I could beat them arm wrestling though.

As mentioned above, Alark and Jeff did the majority of the teaching in the class. They did a lot of work, and did an amazing job organizing all of the logistical details during the in-class portion, and the Doha, Qatar field trip.

The teaching assistants were both very helpful and provided good feedback. They have diverse backgrounds and played different roles (one acting as administrator, the other as more of a student-leader).
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark and Jeff were great TAs. They had to organize everything and did a great job, given the nature of this course.
Instructor: Jeffrey Chow  Unorganized and insensitive.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It's directly relevant to the area I want to go into, international environmental policy.
I have always been interested in international negotiations and the COPs, and wanted to be able to understand what goes on there.
My program will be a series of life experiences like DohA
It fits very well (I'm interested in climate change adaptation, communication, and education).
I have textbook knowledge of international law and policy, but needed more "on-the-ground" experience and knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because it's project-based and one gets to travel.
See previous.
because it is in line with my interests.

This course put into perspective the complexity and frustrations of international law and policy, the difficulties of collaboration (e.g., developing vs. developed countries), and the long and arduous process of making progress in international law. I found it very helpful to better understand the frustrations between scientists and policymakers, and how without proper collaboration and understanding, progress cannot be made. I think this is very helpful to my hopeful future career in environmental consulting, because I will be working with all types of decisionmakers, researchers, and scientists.
It provided an opportunity to interact with a real organization and work on a real project.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, but those who did not get a good client might feel otherwise.
Yes
yes.

Yes - most importantly I gained a lot of knowledge/skills through the mock negotiations. I took this assignment seriously and gained a lot of valuable experience. Now I know the frustrations that decisionmakers endure through these processes, but it helps to have this experience in deciding what my next path will be to better prepare myself for a future career related to international law and policy.
Yes, very much so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: My client group was fantastic, and really on top of everything. It made the work much more manageable and enjoyable.

A devout German,a passionate duality of a real world woman finding a gaze in the eyes of a complement, a comically annoyed blonde realist, a man who says "no talk to driver", and of course I. And who am I?i am the stone that the builder refusedi am the visualthe inspirationthat made lady sings the bluesi'm the spark that makes your idea brightthe same sparkthat lights the darkso that you can know your left from your righti am the ballot in your boxthe bullet in your gunthat inner glowthat lets you knowto call your brother sonthe story that just begunthe promise of what's to comeand imma remain a soldiertil' the war is won

I enjoyed my workgroup because I worked with someone who had a completely different background and we both contributed equally but differently to the assignments. I usually dislike group work assignments, but thisis one course where it is most valuable. Neither of us felt like we had to do the majority of the work, because we were interested in what we were doing and could both contribute separately but equally.
Advantages: having diverse backgrounds.Disadvantages: it was generally difficult to find time that worked for everyone.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure you get a client whose work will help you understand the UNFCCC process.
Find a passionate Czech
if you're interested in international climate change negotiations and the role that int. organization play in them, take this course.

Ask questions - prepare! Read books on the history of international law and policy. Subscribe to blogs related to the topics. Follow them, but do not overwhelm yourself with trying to get "caught up". International law and policy is continually growing and is a largely complex topic. You will never know everything that is happening, so do not feel like you are not doing enough. Ask peers who have taken their course what they suggest you do to prepare or make the most of the assignments, collaboration and overall course. Ask others involved in the field about things you are curious or confused about (e.g., talk to a professor). Also, enjoy yourself. This is a fun course and if you get bogged down and frustrated, you will not be able to make the most out of it.
The fact that students are expected to work with a real organization provides a unique opportunity that is very similar to having an internship with that organization. So it is a great course.
